Perhaps this should also be an exception, as with the earlier patch?

In fact, both changes are likely to break builds if folks already have bad data. I wonder if we want an option to let them disable the checks as a quick way to fix builds. Or are the dependencies for doc builds managed in such a way that reno can be pinned separately in different repos?

> Perhaps this should also be an exception, as with the earlier patch?

Good point. This will result in unused data which has the same end result as the unusable data seen in the earlier patch. With that said...

> In fact, both changes are likely to break builds if folks already have bad data. I wonder if we want an option to let them disable the checks as a quick way to fix builds. Or are the dependencies for doc builds managed in such a way that reno can be pinned separately in different repos?

Personally, I think this is a reasonable thing to break on over the long term. There's a good chance that users didn't spot the mistake until now and will want to correct things. However, we don't want to be user hostile so perhaps we could log a warning for now and only raise an exception in a later release. It's very easy to disable Sphinx's warnings-as-error feature if people wanted a temporary workaround. Certainly, it's no more difficult than adding a new flag that we'd only end up removing in the future, assuming this isn't behavior we'd want to continue supporting long-term.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/commo.message: common/prepare-env appears to be referenced in several restore playbooks, bootstrap ...how will this affect those? could there be duplicates

Yes, if the ansible remote host have a new public key, it'll be added to the known_hosts during bootstrapping, re-storing. re-homing etc. So, whenever the remote host has a new key, it will be added to the known_hosts accumulatively. 
However, as the lineinfile.line is to insert/replace a line into a file. If the hostname and ecdsa public key is alreday existing in the known_hosts, the record line will be identical to the line in remote_keyscan.stdout_lines, in this case, no duplicated record will be inserted.
Mostly, we're running ansible playbook as dcmanager(root), as the /root/.ssh/known_hosts is not backed-up and restored during upgrade, it will mostly have two public keys(newly installed host and the one is going to be restored) for a subcloud's oam address. 
And for the known_hosts of the rest users, as we don't often ssh to the subcloud before bootstrapping, the known host key will be the one we restored.

Glance has two ways to upload an image, the regular way and the import way. Import requires uploading the image to a temporary holding (staging) area, after which the image can be converted before moving to the actual storage location, and potentially be copied to multiple places. This is controlled by the user in a multi-step fashion, and they can leave images in that staging area for a long time. Since it's shared by all tenants and would generally be local disk space on an API worker, it's fundamentally different than the regular storage areas, and more constrained.

nit: extra whitespace compared with line 5748

I think this would make more sense to be moved to _inner_sync_auto_update.

Reason: As the code is written now this represents a check, and _inner_sync_auto_update represent an operation to be done if the check passes. In the future(refactor/reuse component) this can introduce timing issues where (take example of reuse) both checks pass, thus both operations start, which lead armada timeout(or successor of armada).
As a defensive move, just making the check+operation as a group an atomic operation, prevents potential issues.

Actually, thinking it for a second, we don't need to mark the existing PCI device inventories with a 'nova' trait.

If a node with Cyborg-managed GPUs provides VGPU inventories, it will either use a VGPU resource class or a 'CUSTOM_<foo>' resource class (once we merge generic mediated devices spec this cycle) but on a *specific* Resource Provider, which is the physical PCI device.

Here, I think that we should have for Cyborg a different Resource Provider with another name convention and just another custom resource class that *wouldn't* be VGPU.

I have to reevaluate my position.

I think the vGPU provided by Cyborg are totally the same from the user of the VM perspective that the vGPU provided by Nova. Having a cloud that has both nova vGPUs and cyborg vGPUs means that from the user perspective both provides the same functionality. Still the nova API requires the different ways to request them. This is bad. You have two ways to get the same thing. But why? What is the point? Why we complicate things? 

I assume that a deployer only deploys Cyborg to add some value to the cloud. What is that value if Cyborg and Nova provides exactly the same vGPU to the guest and nova already needed to be deployed to create VMs? 

In case of a programmable accelerators I see the difference between the PCI device nova provides via passthrough and a PCI device cyborg provides. The latter one is customized by Cyborg with unique capabilities. And such capabilities are requested by the user. So we can model those capabilities and schedule based on those capabilities. No need to use ownership as the capabilities makes the difference. 

So the whole ownership concept is only needed if two service provides exactly the same thing. As soon as there is a something that is different between the two resources we can schedule based on that difference and we don't need the ownership. In this sense ownership is a artificial quality we want to add as there is no other qualitative difference.

So my recommendation is:

* If there are similar resources only differing in capabilities (e.g. PCI devices with programmability) then use the same resource class but use the different capability represented as traits. So no need to model ownership as traits.
* In General; Forbid to have two services providing exactly the same resource with the same capabilities (for example vGPU from nova and from cyborg).
* Optionally and in particular to the current vGPU situation, allow an exception to the general rule. Allow cyborg to invent a fake capability (not ownership!) along its vGPU support. Represent that as a custom trait. And require that trait in the device profile. Also document that nova vGPU support and cyborg vGPU support cannot be mixed to avoid a resource:vgpu request allocated from a cyborg RP without actually having an arq created.


In the future:

* When we model PCI devices in placement we will have VF resources due to nova+neutron supporting vnic_type=direct ports and also similarly VF resources due to nova+neutron+cyborg supporting programmable smartnics via vnic_type=accelerator_direct. So here the VF resource will either has a (CUSTOM_)VNIC_TYPE_DIRECT or a (CUSTOM_)VNIC_TYPE_DIRECT_ACCELERATOR traits (or similar representing the that one of the VF is accelerated by specific programming while the other isn't). 

* If we ever model cinder storage as DISK_GB in placement along with DISK_GB as local storage in nova then we can use (CUSTOM_)LOCAL_STORAGE and (CUSTOM_)VOLUME_STORAGE to differentiate between DISK_GB resources based the way they are actually connected to the VM (e.g one is attached directly and from locally, the other is attached via the network)

> We had discussion about it on #openstack-nova during and after the weekly meeting. I try to summarize my view here.
> 
> 1) nova managed and cyborg managed vGPU resource is requested differently. The nova managed one uses "resources:VGPU" extra spec in the flavor while cyborg uses a device profile in the flavor. 
> I think this is OK as is. We don't want to support cyborg vGPUs via the "resources:VGPU" syntax. 
> 
> 2) As the two type of vGPUs are always requested explicitly and differently therefore we don't support the use case: "Give me a vGPU, I don't care if it is nova or cyborg managed." I.e. the admin creating the flavor already decides which type of vGPU the flavor requests. The nova conductor and scheduler does not have to choose just follow the request.
> 
> 3) We agreed in this spec that "upgrading" a VM from nova managed vGPUs to cyborg managed vGPUs is a resize operation. 
> 
> => Based on these assumptions keeping the VGPU RC for nova usage and creating a new standard or custom RC for cyborg works for me. Personally I vote for a new standard trait for cyborg vGPUs.
> 

I mean Personally I vote for a new standard RC for cyborg vGPUs.

> The OWNER_ trait opens up a lot of questions when we want to define its meaning:
> * Does OWNER_CYBORG trait on an RP means that _every_ RC on that RP is managed by Cyborg? 
> * Does "managing" here means that only cyborg can report inventories and traits on that RP?
> * Does creating a child RP by service A is allowed if the parent RP owned by service B? 
> * Does cascade deleting allowed by service B even if there are child RPs owned by service A in the tree?
> * Who is responsible to enforce these rules? Placement? Nova? Cyborg? 
> 
> I think we don't want to express ownership (as it is hard) we just want to make sure that what is requested separately in the flavor are also easy to separate in the placement a_c request. If cyborg device profile is mapped to a different RC than nova vgpu request then this separation is easy. Trait based separation also works, but if we want to go there then I would like to avoid discussion full ownership.
This is determined on the W PTG: https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/nova-wallaby-ptg#150.

> 
> 
> if you dont like the user of a trait or a diffent resouce class then aggreates are our only placment native option left or we have to filter in python after the fact which can be problematic if you limit the placement response.
> 
> there is no differen here betwen the cinder case were you agree that each sevice should just use there own trait and the vgpu case where we are disagreing with nova just using it own trait for its gpus. the problem with that appoch is syvalin object to nova every stating "only the nova owned resouces" and that is why i say "forbid cyborg resouces" via the prefilter using a forbiden trait.

I think the difference between the cinder and the cyborg cases the that in the cinder case only cinder needs to know and use the VOLUME_STORAGE trait. Nova only need to know about and use the EPHEMERAL_STORAGE trait. While in the cyborg case, there is no nova only trait that only nova uses, and a cyborg only trait that only cyborg uses. Nova need to hardcode the cyborg trait in the prefilter. In cinder case nova only need to take the cinder resource request as a black box and add it to the a_c query.

But I rest my case. I spent more time on this than what I should considering that I don't need this feature. If the rest of us agrees that having a cyborg only trait hardcoded in nova prefilter is acceptable coupling between cyborg and nova then I will not block on it.

We had discussion about it on #openstack-nova during and after the weekly meeting. I try to summarize my view here.

1) nova managed and cyborg managed vGPU resource is requested differently. The nova managed one uses "resources:VGPU" extra spec in the flavor while cyborg uses a device profile in the flavor. 
I think this is OK as is. We don't want to support cyborg vGPUs via the "resources:VGPU" syntax. 

2) As the two type of vGPUs are always requested explicitly and differently therefore we don't support the use case: "Give me a vGPU, I don't care if it is nova or cyborg managed." I.e. the admin creating the flavor already decides which type of vGPU the flavor requests. The nova conductor and scheduler does not have to choose just follow the request.

3) We agreed in this spec that "upgrading" a VM from nova managed vGPUs to cyborg managed vGPUs is a resize operation. 

=> Based on these assumptions keeping the VGPU RC for nova usage and creating a new standard or custom RC for cyborg works for me. Personally I vote for a new standard trait for cyborg vGPUs.

The OWNER_ trait opens up a lot of questions when we want to define its meaning:
* Does OWNER_CYBORG trait on an RP means that _every_ RC on that RP is managed by Cyborg? 
* Does "managing" here means that only cyborg can report inventories and traits on that RP?
* Does creating a child RP by service A is allowed if the parent RP owned by service B? 
* Does cascade deleting allowed by service B even if there are child RPs owned by service A in the tree?
* Who is responsible to enforce these rules? Placement? Nova? Cyborg? 

I think we don't want to express ownership (as it is hard) we just want to make sure that what is requested separately in the flavor are also easy to separate in the placement a_c request. If cyborg device profile is mapped to a different RC than nova vgpu request then this separation is easy. Trait based separation also works, but if we want to go there then I would like to avoid discussion full ownership.

> the CUSTOM_VNIC_TYPE_DIRECT approch will not be as trait for ward as i think you are assuming but it might work.
> 
> in terms of the excption for cyborg for vGPUS the new trait need to be something that is encudied in the nova prefilter.
> 
> as we will have to use a forbidn triat for the exsiting nova vgpu feature.

I don't want to encode a cyborg specific trait into a nova feature that is independent from the cyborg feature. This is why I suggested simply documenting that the two vgpu feature should not be mixed. 

In the VF and DISK_GB cases we don't need the forbidden trait at all. In those cases it is enough to require the positive trait only. E.g. the nova feature handling DISK_GB as local disk only needs to know about and include require=LOCAL_STORAGE and does not have to know about the existence of VOLUME_STORAGE trait at all. Similarly cinder only need to know and use the VOLUME_STORAGE trait.

 
> 
> (CUSTOM_)LOCAL_STORAGE and (CUSTOM_)VOLUME_STORAGE  i think does work well for cinder but again nova will need to know what these trait are and append them automatically with a prefilter
> 
> e.g. when not boot form volume it will have to report local storage CUSTOM_LOCAL_STORAGE and request it with the same trait.

I imagine the cinder interface the same way as what we have with neutron. So cinder will tell us what resource to allocate for a given volume with what traits. 

> 
> because of the ceph backend and the fact we support puting the libvirt/nova state dir on an nfs share we sould also avoid local and use EPHEMERAL_STORAGE instaead as it may not be local.
> 

Yeah EPHEMERAL_STORAGE probably a better name.


> 
> so i think the path forward in the VGPU case your  are recommending is 
> 
> 1 nova an neutron use the vGPU resouce class
> 2 cyborg will report it with a known trait that is not a ower trait
> 3 the device filter will contianed the required trait 
> 4 a prefilter will be provided to add it as a forbiden trait when we have resouces:vgpu
>   and this prefilt will be configurable so that deployment without cyborg do not need to use it.

I know that this helps fully separating the nova and the cyborg feature and it allows using both in the same deployment. But I don't like the fact that nova needs to know and hardcode a purely cyborg related trait.

> 5 nova will not be modified to report any trait for the vgpu resouces it reports today
> 
> is ^ correct
See, if we do the above, Cyborg flavors could just ask for RCs like CUSTOM_CYBORG_MY_TYPE=1 and as VGPU resources would be only for Nova, it shouldn't be a problem.

zuul/zk/config_cache.py.message:
Translating this code I get:

  If the most recent timestamp of the zookeeper file cache cache is older than the logical timestamp of the event, then it is outdated.

That's based on update_ltime meaning "the most recent timestamp of the zookeeper file cache" (this class), and cache_ltime being "the logical timestamp of the event" (the input argument we're checking against).

I think perhaps calling the argument cache_ltime is confusing; I think the idea is that we want a cache that is at least as new as the argument.  So maybe we should, at least in this method, and probably in some of the call sites as well, name the argument "updated_since" or "required_ltime" or "newer_than_ltime" or something along those lines?
Wouldn't the cache be outdated if its ltime is less than the update_ltime in the zookeeper content? It seems like this is backwards?

pkg/cluster/clustermap/map.go.message: you should add this method to the interface on line 37 in order to make it work, otherwise unit tests will continue to fail and you won't have an ability to call this method since we are using interface of ClusterMap
this method is not used anywhere except unit test

The validation concept introduced here seems not effective. how do you plan to use this method?
I believe the main intention of this method should be to validate whole ClusterMap, to not verify that two input strings are not equal.
the workflow of this method seems to me as follows:
* iterate over each cluster in clusterMap
* check whether the cluster has a parent;
* if cluster has a parent, it should be verified as well as all nested parents: each parent should exist and has no parent with child's name (preventing circular dependencies - that's the essence of the linked issue #481).

currently, no whole CM checks and circular dependencies verification introduced.

Won't this cause an error with our default cluster map? https://github.com/airshipit/airshipctl/blob/master/manifests/phases/cluster-map.yaml

The parentClusters slice would contain one cluster: the ephemeral-cluster; however, the childCluster is also the ephemeral-cluster after the loop above exits on L80.

we'd probably see better performance using a map[string]bool or a map[string]struct{} here for the O(1) lookups instead of this O(n) loop. I can't imagine anyone ever having so many parent clusters that this becomes a bottleneck (so it's largely academic), but I wouldn't be opposed to a followup change which swaps out the data structures

cgcs-root/centos-repo/Binary.

It's the job of generate-centos-repo.sh to construct cgcs-root/centos-repo/Binary, based on the rpm type lst files.  Each listed rpm gets a symlink to the downloaded rpm under stx-tools/centos-mirror-tools/output/stx/CentOS/Binary.  Rpm's not in an rpm type lst files are not symlinked, and are unavailable to the build.

2) Change the docs and jenkins build scripts to run populate_downloads.sh ahead of generate-centos-repo.sh.  Then add a new download method to field 4 of *tarball-dl.lst files.  And then modify generate-centos-repo.sh to start scanning *tarball-dl.lst, looking for the new method as a trigger to pull rpms from the download directory into the yum repo.  field 5 would have to be abused to list the actual rpms to be added to the yum repo.

I hate both.

I probably hate option 1 less

got

I think preventing the proxy from starting is a somewhat hostile position for what is ostensibly a new feature to assist operators.

I think something more like a "config check" tool/function would be a lot more useful and operator friendly.
Another: https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1909213

swift/proxy/server.py.message: The dependency is called "soft" yet the comment says "must". This is incongruent.
I see. Well, can they be something like opt_filter_deps, perhaps? Just cutting the gordean knot by omitting the softness.

...immediately prefaced by "if present". Do you have a better name in mind?

In general, we don't have hard middleware dependencies -- the closest we get is

- s3api, where deploying slo or encryption enables some features but you can still deploy without them, or
- slo, which imports some bulk-deleter code but doesn't actually issue a request for the bulk middleware to process.

This is different; slo doesn't require symlinks -- each feature can be toggled independently. But if symlink is left of slo, we know we aren't going to be able to pass func tests, because we can't replace a segment with a symlink that points to the same data.

So what's a better name for "if I am enabled *and* this thing is enabled, it needs to be down stream of me"? Or, what's a better wording for documenting it?

this would be great if it was separate function

this would be better if there was a "unsafe_skip_pipeline_validation" option since it could easily cause a failure to start proxies after reboot

... give effected users a chance to file a bug a cycle to get a fix or figure out a migration plan for their pipeline

I think designing it to be consumed by tools that are generating configs (e.g. someone's chef/ansible or the SwiftStack Controller) is absolutely useful - perhaps even more useful than running it here inline when it's kind of too late.

I can't say when/if YOU personally would want to allow bypassing this check - since you can always just write a patch - but any operator that was running with a misordered pipeline that we didn't previously disallow might appreciate an obvious way to keep doing what they were doing knowing they won't make it *worse* while they can meanwhile file a bug or get in #openstack-swift and try and validate if all the data in their cluster is still going to "work" after the recommended pipeline reordering, or if they need a lengthy migration before they can switch over.

IDK how useful this would be as a separate function... we're checking a PipelineWrapper, which seems like a bit of a heavy lift for most callers...

Maybe it would mostly still work with a list of names? Provided, of course, that whoever calls it uses the same entry point names...

As far as a config option to override... I kinda wonder if we should expose allow_modify_pipeline in proxy-server.conf... I kinda remember Sam wanting to be able to say, "No, seriously, I *don't want* a gatekeeper!"

IDK how much I really want to enable bypassing this though -- I've tried to be pretty conservative in terms of making sure that these are known-bad configs with clear repercussions; it's part of why I wanted to establish a precedent of including comments per-check explaining why we feel like it's a thing worth preventing the proxy from coming up.

*Maybe* I shouldn't have included the slo -> symlink, dlo -> symlink, and staticweb -> symlink checks? All the others, Swift is likely to 500 a very broad class of requests, with the sorts of tracebacks that just lead us down rabbit holes.

All right, a *tool* that takes a config file, loads it up, finds pipeline:main, gets a PipelineWrapper with all the goodness needed to actually run this -- I suppose I could see that.

Next logical step would be to also validate that the config values are sane and won't make the proxy barf. Maybe even make sure that any keystone/pykmip creds are valid... This is starting to sound an awful lot like swift-proxy-server but one step short of actually listening on a socket.

> keep doing what they were doing knowing they won't make it *worse*

IDK -- I think it's pretty clear that things can and will get worse the longer you run with a pipeline that trips https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1813725

I realize that I've taken a bit of a hostile stance -- but it's also not something that I've done lightly. There are two main themes to the deps I specified:

- listing_formats needs to be far left. The alternative is *you cannot do container listings*.
- encryption needs to be far right. The alternative is *your data is not actually encrypted* (for formpost or copy), *your data is corrupted* (for dlo), or *large features of swift do not work* (for slo, s3api, bulk, maybe others).

> if they need a lengthy migration before they can switch over

That's the bit that made me think of this in the context of hardlinks -- without *some* way to ensure that symlink really is right of slo and dlo, are we setting users up to need to do some sort of stop-the-world data migration to get back on the happy path? Or are we going to get lucky and hardlink-to-large-object just *won't work*?
should probably add symlink here, right?

I'm not actually sure that it would caues a problem currently. Once we have https://review.opendev.org/#/c/633857/ absolutely this should be updated. But until then, func tests pass (at least on my machine!) with *either* versioned_writes-then-symlink OR symlink-then-versioned_writes.

then use with "zuul_locks.locked"

Here though, since _get_scheduler_hints raises "TypeError: argument of type '_SentinelObject' is not iterable" when the sentinel is used, it skips the call to _prep_resize and so TestingException doesn't get raised. centos_tarball-dl.lst.message: Similar concern to the dpdk download.  The revision field to checkout has origin/rhel8/fpga-ofs-dev-5.10-lts in it, but if that is an active branch as opposed to a tag, then everybody downloading that source tarball is potentially getting a different version as commits are pushed to it.

The field after "git" is the revision field which you have left blank ie. #git##.  You should have the version to checkout in it, ie. #git#2a9f0f72a2d926382634cf8f1de10e1acf57542b#

Using git commit ids is kind of a last resort, you should really use release-based tags if there are any in the repo.

Please drop "post-dl-script/qat1.7.sh" off the end of that line, separate download scripts are not used (we just have the one global download script that you have been changing).  Effectively anything in that last field is just ignored anyway, but leaving stuff in there that is not used is just confusing to people.  The original design of these .lst files allowed for separate download scripts but that was never implemented.

Two points here.  1.  We have to use a different fpga source version than what you have here.  See my comment in the other review.  This makes 2 a moot point but I will mention it anyway:

2.  The field after "git" ie. origin/rhel8/fpga...  is the one that maps onto the $util var and is what you will checkout in the script.  The commit id in the next field ie. the last field "script" is effectively ignored, don't hijack it for other uses.  Checking out an active branch means that every person who downloads may get different source.  That would be bad.  Checking out a tag that represents a released version, however, would be very good.  In the absence of such tags in the repo, then you need to checkout a specific commit id.  The name of the downloaded tarball would also have to reflect the exact version downloaded and not just be the name of an active branch.  I assume that a branch with lts (long term support) on the name of it is an active branch.

Please see my comments in the download script as well.

You are right! not a good way to fix this issue, I will replace all the executing python as python3

I don't like having this as a function.

Can't we just make sure we always install python3 and replace the calls to "python" with "python3"? We dropped support for centos7 in the meantime, so there shouldn't be any blocker.

That should be an easier way and same as patchset 1....
I will update as you said and then look forward to the result of CI

As PYTHON_VERSION cannot be empty (as stated above) and python2 command is not available on some architectures then this implicitely remove support for python2!

To workaround this situation please allow to specify PYTHON_EXECUTABLE by hand:

 export PYTHON_EXECUTABLE={PYTHON_EXECUTABLE:-$(find_python_executable "${PYTHON_VERSION}")}

Then implement find_python_executable more smartly to introduce support for well known python versions. For example:

 function find_python_executable {
   local version=${1:-3}
   if  [[ "${version}" =~ ^2.* ]]; then
       local names=( "python${version}" python2 python )
   elif  [[ "${version}" =~ ^3.* ]]; then
       local names=( "python${version}" python3 python )
   else
       die ...  # Invalid Python version: "${version}"
   fi

   for name in "${names[@]}"; then
       local executable=$(which "${name}" || true)
       if [ -x "${executable}" ]; then
           if "${executable}" --version 2>&1 | grep "^Python ${version}"; then
               echo "${executable}"
               return 0
            fi
       fi
   done

   die ... # No such executable for required Python version: "${version}"
 }

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: is this runtime manifest idempotent/reentrant?  i.e. can it be structured to run again in case of failure?
Yes it can run again in case of failure. Actually this is how we are handling failures in this step, in case the operation fails user will be able to run it again.

what permissions and ownership are being created on this directory. 
should it be declared here explicitly?

Both the directory and the files created under it are being created with the same permissions and ownership as the /tmp directory, e.g., root. I think as is the same as the parent directory we don't need to explicitly indicate it at the manifest class, do you think it's better to declare it?
In the end of this class execution the temporary directory we create will be removed.

I think you are fine.  if an error occurs and the 'rm' is not invoked,
 presumably the folder and files might be left behind. 
 so the only concern would be if re-executing will overwrite the files, or will re-use a stale entry.
another concern would be if the permissions are too wide open, and there is anything in there that we need to not be visible  to non root.

Same comment as for the directory.  does file permissions and ownership need to be explicit
Same comment for all new files and directories in this review.

shouldn't this directory have executable permissions also?
In my env, if I create a  640 directory, I cannot then create a file under that directory
I thought on allowing just the root user or group to create files under this directory. Did you try it using sudo? Or as root user? In my mind root permissions would enhance some security measures...

What I did was:
mkdir /tmp/foo
chmod 640 /tmp/foo
touch /tmp/foo/file.txt

creating the file.txt was prevented because the 640 permissions on the directory.
If you already have a folder /tmp/kube_rootca_update, I think it will re-use it rather than trying to create one with those permissions.

I think on your last command if you run 'sudo touch /tmp/foo/file.txt' the file will be created. As puppet is running as user root I guess this permission won't be a problem.

Thinking on eventual problems, if the manifest fails and for some reason the directory doesn't be removed, it's fine to re-run the manifest (possibly with the problem solved). Even with this behavior of non-overwriting the content already there, unless the content of the respective file is changed also, shouldn't be a problem as if one file content is changed, it will be changed. Same as for the permissions of each file/directory.

Do you can see any problems with this approach? Or how it could be better?
Looks like root (or sudo) does not care about the execute permissions.  So I suspect this code is fine as long as the puppet code continues to be run as root.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/te.message: what is the expected behaviour when rollout status fails the status check?
Did you test that the procedure actually fails when the rollout fails?
Sorry, not "all pods" but "all deployments and daemonsets". Pods that doesn't belong to any of them should be manually restarted by the user

Yes! The watch flag will block execution while the pods aren't running healthy into the system. What can happen is the case in which the pod struggles to go up in a 10minutes window, then the rollout will fail and procedure will fail too.
This execution should fail and consequently the state of this phase of the procedure should fail. Then, the user will be able to re-execute the rollout restart for all pods.
